awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Creating mechanisms to make integrative structures of large macromolecular assemblies available from the Protein Data Bank
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop the necessary infrastructure to make the integrative structures of biomolecular systems available from the Protein Data Bank (PDB). PDB is the single global repository for three-dimensional structures of biological macromolecules and their complexes. It is used by millions of scientists and educators worldwide. This project will provide open access to integrative structures through the PDB, which will greatly enhance the understanding of cellular and molecular biology and speed the progress of biomedical and biotechnology research. The project is central to the creation of an interoperating network of structural biology resources that will provide seamless access to research data and promote efficient data sharing. This work will significantly advance biological research by making structures of complex macromolecular assemblies easily accessible to everyone through the PDB.

Increasingly, structures of many complex biological assemblies are determined using integrative approaches, in which data from multiple experimental methods are combined. The PDB archives structures determined using single methods and needs to be expanded to handle these integrative structures. In the last three years, a standalone prototype system, called PDB-Dev, has been developed for archiving integrative structures and making them publicly available. The current project will integrate the PDB-Dev system with the PDB data processing pipeline and ensure that the integrative structures are made available from the PDB according to the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) principles. Integration of PDB-Dev with the PDB will enable the broad and growing community of PDB users to have access to an even richer and more diverse set of curated structural models. The project will create a rigorous standardized process for deposition, curation, validation, archival, and dissemination of integrative structures through the PDB. This functionality will facilitate tackling increasingly more challenging structure determination problems such as elucidation of the three-dimensional structures of complete genomes and even the creation of a spatiotemporal model of an entire cell. The results of the project can be accessed from the PDB-Dev website: https://pdb-dev.wwpdb.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Award Title: Collaborative Research: Creating mechanisms to make integrative structures of large macromolecular assemblies available from the Protein Data Bank

Federal Award ID: DBI-2112968

Report Submission Period: 09/01/2021 to 08/31/2024 

Increasingly, structures of many complex biological systems are determined using integrative modeling approaches that involve combining data from multiple experimental and computational methods to build the structures of complex macromolecular assemblies. We have previously developed a standalone system, called PDB-Dev for depositing and archiving integrative structures and making them publicly available. The system was implemented separately from the Protein Data Bank (PDB) to deliver an agile and timely solution for the evolving field of structural biology. This current project subsequently integrates the operational PDB-Dev system with the PDB data processing workflow and ensures that the integrative structures are made available from the PDB according to the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) principles. After unification with PDB, PDB-Dev has been rebranded as PDB-IHM (PDB Integrated and Hybrid Methods). 

The significant outcomes of this research project are: 

  1. Integrative structures are now delivered alongside experimental structures in the PDB archive and are available for download from files.wwpdb.org. These structures are processed through PDB-IHM (data.pdb-ihm.org), in parallel to the wwPDB OneDep system. 

  2. Integrative structures have been issued PDB accession codes and digital object identifiers (DOIs) and can be accessed from wwpdb.org and pdb-ihm.org. All released entries have been remediated to incorporate new PDB accession codes as primary identifiers. 

  3. Data standards have been created and extended for representing integrative modeling investigations. A comprehensive system has been developed for collecting, processing, and distributing integrative structures. 

  4. PDB-IHM has been expanded to support bulk submission of multiple entries belonging to an investigation or publication.

  5. The PDB-IHM curation and release processes have been streamlined to align with and conform to the PDB curation and release process and policies. Synchronized workflows have been created to enable coordinated weekly releases of integrative and experimental structures in the PDB archive. 

  6. Methods of evaluating the quality of integrative structures have been developed and implemented as part of the deposition, curation, and release process. Assessment metrics include estimation of data and model quality as well as fit of the structure to the experimental data. Validation reports are available for download alongside integrative structures. 

  7. PDB-IHM data dissemination website (pdb-ihm.org) has been updated to support both PDB and PDB-Dev accession codes. The website facilitates search, retrieval, and visualization of integrative structures.     

This project has enabled the creation of a data pipeline for deposition, biocuration, validation, visualization, archiving, and dissemination of integrative structures. PDB-IHM has made key structures of biological assemblies freely available to researchers, educators, and students around the world. PDB-IHM currently consists of more than 340 released structures with additional structures that are either on hold for publication or are being processed. PDB-IHM has enabled archiving integrative structures of large, complex, and dynamic macromolecular networks and machinery that drive fundamental biological processes such as replication, transcription, translation, genomic regulation, DNA repair, protein degradation, movement of proteins across the nuclear membrane, and immune response. PDB-IHM thus promotes the FAIR principles and impacts scientists and educators who use structural biology models and data for their research. 

With recent breakthroughs in computational biology leading to the successful application of machine learning algorithms to build computed structures models of macromolecules, integrative structural biology is entering a new phase, where the starting structures of macromolecular components of large assemblies are readily available. Experimental techniques that provide restraint information to assemble components of biomolecular complexes can now use these starting models to build integrative structures of assemblies on a large scale. Biophysical methods that carry information regarding the dynamics of these complexes can provide additional insights into their function. Creating a rigorous standardized process for deposition, curation, validation, archiving, and dissemination of integrative structures empowers the scientific community to tackle very large structure determination challenges such as elucidation of the three-dimensional structures of complete genomes and even the creation of a spatiotemporal model of an entire cell.

The outcomes of this project ensure that the results of integrative structural biology investigations are uniformly curated, archived and made available alongside the PDB experimental structures to the scientific community and the general public for utilization towards the advancement of worldwide education, healthcare, and research. Specifically, open access to integrative structures of macromolecular systems greatly enhances the understanding of biomolecular structure and function, thus catalyzing the progress of biological and biomedical research. In addition, the project enables a growing user community to study and understand molecular function at the structural level in areas ranging from cellular and molecular biology to nanotechnology and biomolecular design.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Carl F Kesselman
por.por_txt_cntn:
Award Title: Collaborative Research: Creating mechanisms to make integrative structures of large macromolecular assemblies available from the Protein Data Bank


Federal Award ID: DBI-2112968


Report Submission Period: 09/01/2021 to 08/31/2024


Increasingly, structures of many complex biological systems are determined using integrative modeling approaches that involve combining data from multiple experimental and computational methods to build the structures of complex macromolecular assemblies. We have previously developed a standalone system, called PDB-Dev for depositing and archiving integrative structures and making them publicly available. The system was implemented separately from the Protein Data Bank (PDB) to deliver an agile and timely solution for the evolving field of structural biology. This current project subsequently integrates the operational PDB-Dev system with the PDB data processing workflow and ensures that the integrative structures are made available from the PDB according to the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) principles. After unification with PDB, PDB-Dev has been rebranded as PDB-IHM (PDB Integrated and Hybrid Methods).


The significant outcomes of this research project are:




Integrative structures are now delivered alongside experimental structures in the PDB archive and are available for download from files.wwpdb.org. These structures are processed through PDB-IHM (data.pdb-ihm.org), in parallel to the wwPDB OneDep system.




Integrative structures have been issued PDB accession codes and digital object identifiers (DOIs) and can be accessed from wwpdb.org and pdb-ihm.org. All released entries have been remediated to incorporate new PDB accession codes as primary identifiers.




Data standards have been created and extended for representing integrative modeling investigations. A comprehensive system has been developed for collecting, processing, and distributing integrative structures.




PDB-IHM has been expanded to support bulk submission of multiple entries belonging to an investigation or publication.




The PDB-IHM curation and release processes have been streamlined to align with and conform to the PDB curation and release process and policies. Synchronized workflows have been created to enable coordinated weekly releases of integrative and experimental structures in the PDB archive.




Methods of evaluating the quality of integrative structures have been developed and implemented as part of the deposition, curation, and release process. Assessment metrics include estimation of data and model quality as well as fit of the structure to the experimental data. Validation reports are available for download alongside integrative structures.




PDB-IHM data dissemination website (pdb-ihm.org) has been updated to support both PDB and PDB-Dev accession codes. The website facilitates search, retrieval, and visualization of integrative structures.




This project has enabled the creation of a data pipeline for deposition, biocuration, validation, visualization, archiving, and dissemination of integrative structures. PDB-IHM has made key structures of biological assemblies freely available to researchers, educators, and students around the world. PDB-IHM currently consists of more than 340 released structures with additional structures that are either on hold for publication or are being processed. PDB-IHM has enabled archiving integrative structures of large, complex, and dynamic macromolecular networks and machinery that drive fundamental biological processes such as replication, transcription, translation, genomic regulation, DNA repair, protein degradation, movement of proteins across the nuclear membrane, and immune response. PDB-IHM thus promotes the FAIR principles and impacts scientists and educators who use structural biology models and data for their research.


With recent breakthroughs in computational biology leading to the successful application of machine learning algorithms to build computed structures models of macromolecules, integrative structural biology is entering a new phase, where the starting structures of macromolecular components of large assemblies are readily available. Experimental techniques that provide restraint information to assemble components of biomolecular complexes can now use these starting models to build integrative structures of assemblies on a large scale. Biophysical methods that carry information regarding the dynamics of these complexes can provide additional insights into their function. Creating a rigorous standardized process for deposition, curation, validation, archiving, and dissemination of integrative structures empowers the scientific community to tackle very large structure determination challenges such as elucidation of the three-dimensional structures of complete genomes and even the creation of a spatiotemporal model of an entire cell.


The outcomes of this project ensure that the results of integrative structural biology investigations are uniformly curated, archived and made available alongside the PDB experimental structures to the scientific community and the general public for utilization towards the advancement of worldwide education, healthcare, and research. Specifically, open access to integrative structures of macromolecular systems greatly enhances the understanding of biomolecular structure and function, thus catalyzing the progress of biological and biomedical research. In addition, the project enables a growing user community to study and understand molecular function at the structural level in areas ranging from cellular and molecular biology to nanotechnology and biomolecular design.
